Good question. Yes you can pair pleasure with eating healthy foods. This is called classical conditioning. Here's a perfect example. Pavlov rings the bell every time a steak is ready for his dogs to eat. The dogs smell the steak and they start to salivate. Over time as Pavlov rung the bell, and then the dogs smelled the steak and salivated, they were able to salivate after hearing the bell without any steak present. Professional animal trainers use this technique all the time to train animals...

Kind of a pointless question, as music is purely subjective.  What one person likes, the other one won't like.  That's why there's a huge variety in music.  To ask what form of music makes the brain react more vigorously is kind of like saying what style of literature is more enjoyable and engaging to read.

Music styles and what people like is highly subjective, thus the music effects their brain differently, your friend might not LOOK happier, he probably is happier.  Heavy metal is no different than other types of music as far as chemical effects go.  Because you aren't a fan of heavy music, that doesn't mean it doesn't make the listener feel better.  Several studies have been conducted on this, and researchers found that metal gets the same reaction as other forms of music.

Actually, dopamine is not the "feel good" hormone. Oxytocin is. Dopamine is the "pursuit" hormone. Hence the reason why it's associated with behaviors like surfing the internet for a long time in pursuit of more information. The two work hand in hand with each other, but dopamine has long been considered the "feel good" hormone when it isn't.

The fact that it is intertwined with our reward system in a quantifiable way, suggests that it evolved to reinforce basic biological behaviours with high adaptive value. Actually, while the dopamine release may seem somewhat 'obvious', it had not been scientifically tested or understood until last year (2011)! Acid rain forms when water vapor condenses in the atmosphere and mixes with the gases, like carbon dioxide, nitrogen, sulfur dioxide, and other greenhouse gases which forms acids; e.g HS2O4. Pure water has a PH of 7, rain that has a PH of less than 7 is considered as acidic, but the common PH level of rain is from 5-6. It's only considered acid rain when it reaches below 4.
